issues.text: Whether the dispute regarding standard rent contemplated by s.12(3)(b) must have been raised before service of the notice under s.12(2)?

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in s. 12 to support the contention raised by Mr. Chatterjee on behalf of the plaintiff that the dispute concerning standard rent contemplated by cl. b of sub-s. 3 is one which must have been raised before service of the notice under s. 12 2 .

issues.text: Whether the defendant continued to pay or tender rent regularly till the suit was finally decided so as to qualify for protection under s.12(3)(b)?

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the defendant did not continue to pay rent regularly till the suit was finally decided, and that deprived him of the protection under s. 12 3 b .

holdings.reasoning_summary: District Court had jurisdiction to decide readiness and willingness under s.12(1); any error in application of s.12(3)(b) was not jurisdictional defect, illegal act, or material irregularity; s.115 limited to such cases per precedents like Privy Council and Supreme Court cases.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 3 b requires the tenant to pay the standard rent, and not interim rent, and for the purpose of that clause the expression standard rent may not be equated with interim rent specified under s. 11 3 .

precedents.cited_proposition: the expression may has a mandatory content if the conditions of the clause are fulfilled the Court is bound to pass a decree in ejectment

anchor.surface_text: As observed by the Privy Council in Balakrishna Udayar v. Vasudeva Aiyar 1  section  s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure  applies to jurisdiction alone, the irregular exercise or number- exercise of it, or illegal assumption of it. The section is number directed against companyclusions of law or fact in which the question of jurisdiction is number involved . Therefore if the Trial Court had jurisdiction to decide a question before it and did decide it, whether it decided it rightly or wrongly, the Court had jurisdiction to decide the case, and even if it decided the question wrongly, it did number exercise its jurisdiction illegally or with material irregularity

precedents.cited_proposition: section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure applies to jurisdiction alone, the irregular exercise or non-exercise of it, or illegal assumption of it. The section is not directed against conclusions of law or fact in which the question of jurisdiction is not involved

precedents.citation: Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 2

anchor.surface_text: irregularity Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 2 . Mr. Chatterjee for the plaintiff companytended that the District Court in declining to pass a decree in ejectment refused to exercise a jurisdiction vested in it by law, and therefore the case fell within the terms of cl.  b  of s. Counsel relied in support of his plea upon Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Laksha Chaudhury and others 3 . In Joy Chand Lals case a , an application for relief under ss. 30 and 36 of the Bengal MoneyLenders Act was dismissed by the Subordinate Judge on the view that the loan in question was a companymercial loan which did number fall within the terms of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: if the Trial Court had jurisdiction to decide a question before it and did decide it, whether it decided it rightly or wrongly, the Court had jurisdiction to decide the case, and even if it decided the question wrongly, it did not exercise its jurisdiction illegally or with material irregularity

precedents.citation: Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Laksha Chaudhury and others 3

anchor.surface_text: Counsel relied in support of his plea upon Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Laksha Chaudhury and others 3 . In Joy Chand Lals case a , an application for relief under ss. 30 and 36 of the Bengal MoneyLenders Act was dismissed by the Subordinate Judge on the view that the loan in question was a companymercial loan which did number fall within the terms of the Act. The Judge however proceeded to companysider whether the suit in which the application was made was a suit to which the Act applied, and held that it was such a suit. The High Court of Calcutta set aside the order. In appeal the Privy Council agreed with the High Court that the Subordinate Judge was bound, upon his finding that the loan was a companymercial loan, to dismiss the application without determining whether the suit was one to which the Act applied.

precedents.case_name: Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Laksha Chaudhury and others
precedents.cited_proposition: although error in a decision of a Subordinate Court does not by itself involve that the Subordinate Court has acted illegally or with material irregularity so as to justify interference in revision under sub-s. (c), nevertheless, if the erroneous decision results in the Subordinate Court exercising a jurisdiction not vested in it by law, or failing to exercise a jurisdiction so vested, a case for revision arises under sub-s. (a) or sub-s. (b)

precedents.citation: Manindra Land and Building Corporation v. Bhutnath Bannerjee and others 1

anchor.surface_text: This was pointed out by this Court in Manindra Land and Building Corporation v. Bhutnath Bannerjee and others 1  wherein after referring to the passage already quoted and another passage from the judgment in Joy Chand Lals case 2 , the Court observed These remarks are number applicable to the facts of the present case. They apply to cases in which the law definitely ousts the jurisdiction of the Court to try a certain dispute between the parties and number to cases in which there is numbersuch ouster of jurisdiction under the provisions of any law, but where it is left to the Court itself to determine certain matters as a result  1  1964 3 S.C.R. 495.  2  L.H. 76 I.A. 131 of which determination the Court has to pass a certain order and may, if necessary, proceed to decide the dispute between the parties.

precedents.case_name: Manindra Land and Building Corporation v. Bhutnath Bannerjee and others
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between cases in which on a wrong decision the Court either assumes jurisdiction which is not vested in it or refuses to exercise jurisdiction which is vested in it by law, and those in which in exercise of its jurisdiction the Court arrives at a conclusion erroneous in law or in fact

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was in error in setting aside the decree of the District Court in exercise of the powers in revision under s. 115 Code of Civil Procedure. The appeal must therefore be allowed and the order passed by the District Court restored. If any amount has

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; District Court decree restored (ejectment suit dismissed, standard rent fixed at Rs. 70 per month with adjustment of deposits)
directions: If any amount has been deposited as standard rent since the order passed by the District Court, the same should be paid over to the plaintiff at the rate of Rs. 70 per month.

Conferral of jurisdiction on subordinate courts by Section 28(1)(b) grounds the holding that High Court erred in exercising revisional powers under s.115 CPC.

The provision in Section 29(1)(b) Bombay Rents Act regarding appeals to the District Court grounds the holding that the High Court lacked jurisdiction under s.115 CPC to interfere with the District Court order.
Section 29(1)(b) Bombay Rents Act, specifying appeals from subordinate judge to District Court, addresses the issue of High Court jurisdiction under s.115 CPC by providing the proper appellate route.
Section 29(2) Bombay Rents Act prohibiting further appeals beyond District Court grounds the holding that the High Court lacked authority to interfere via s.115 CPC revision.
The prohibition on further appeals under Section 29(2) Bombay Rents Act addresses the jurisdictional question of High Court's power under s.115 CPC.
